fr:mainmatter.fr:p: We define the scheme \mathbf {G}_{m} as \operatorname {Spec} \mathbb {Z}[x, x^{-1}]. It can be characterized by the points \hom (\mathbf {G}_{m}, \operatorname {Spec} R) = R^\times being the units of R. This scheme has a group structure. Since it is affine, 1 \to \mathbf {G}_{m} is given by the ring homomorphism \mathbb {Z}[x, x^{-1}] \to \mathbb Z sending x to 1. The product map is given by a ring homomorphism \mathbb {Z}[x, x^{-1}] \otimes \mathbb {Z}[y, y^{-1}] \to \mathbb {Z}[z, z^{-1}] (where we renamed the variables for clarity) sending x \otimes y to z. The inverse map \mathbb {Z}[x, x^{-1}] \to \mathbb {Z}[x, x^{-1}] sends x to x^{-1}.
Given a ring R, a \mathbb {Z}-grading on R is the same as a \mathbf {G}_{m}-action on \operatorname {Spec} R, where \mathbf {G}_{m} is the scheme of invertible elements.

A morphism \rho : \mathbf {G}_{m} \times \operatorname {Spec} R \to \operatorname {Spec} R is given by a ring homomorphism R \to \mathbb {Z}[x, x^{-1}] \otimes R \cong R[x, x^{-1}]. Composing with the identity 1 \to \mathbf {G}_{m}, we are required that R \xrightarrow {\rho } R[x, x^{-1}] \xrightarrow {x \mapsto 1} R is the identity.

We can regard R[x, x^{-1}] as generated by (n, r) \in \mathbb {Z} \times R, where the first number is the degree of x and the second number is the coefficient. So they are under the relations (n, r) + (n, r') = (n, r + r'), and (n, r) \cdot (m, r') = (n + m, r r'). \rho (r) is a sum of finitely many (n, r_n), and the identity law requires the sum of r_n is r again. This decomposes r into its components in each degree.

Next, the associativity law essentially requires that, if (n, r_n) is a summand of some \rho (r), then \rho (r_n) = (n, r_n). So this is indeed a well-defined decomposition. Furthermore, \rho being a ring homomorphism guarantees that the grading respects multiplication and addition.

Morphism of affine schemes are in natural bijection with ring homomorphisms in the opposite direction. In other words, there is a fully faithful embedding \mathsf {CRing}^\textrm {op} \to \mathsf {Sch}.

Given two rings R, S, a ring homomorphism \varphi : S \to R naturally induces a map of distinguished opens f \mapsto \varphi (f). This is a continuous map \operatorname {Spec}(R) \to \operatorname {Spec}(S), because \varphi preserves \operatorname {lcm} and \gcd on radical ideals. For the structure sheaf, we can use the distinguished basis, thus we need to supply a ring homomorphism \Gamma (D(s), \mathscr {O}_{\operatorname {Spec}(S)}) \to \Gamma (D(r), \mathscr {O}_{\operatorname {Spec}(R)}) whenever D(r) \subseteq \varphi ^{-1}D(s) = D(\varphi (s)). This is just a homomorphism S[s^{-1}] \to R[r^{-1}], which is obvious because \varphi (s) must be invertible in R[r^{-1}].

We need to prove our map is local. Using the characterization on stalks, we just need to verify that S_{\varphi ^{-1}(\mathfrak {p})} \to R_{\mathfrak {p}} reflects invertibility. This is true by construction. Hence we have a map \hom _{\mathsf {CRing}}(S, R) \to \hom _{\mathsf {Sch}}(\operatorname {Spec}(R), \operatorname {Spec}(S)).
An affine scheme is a locally ringed space of the form \operatorname {Spec}(R) for some commutative ring R.
